STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER
LANS ING
ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
May 15, 2024
Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Guiding Harbor
525 E Huron River Dr,
Belleville, MI, 48111-3665
RE: License#: CB820201144
Dear Ms. Trotter:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed
on 5/3/2024. An exit confernce was held with you on 5/7/2024. Due to the violations of
applicable licensing rules, a written corrective action plan is required. The corrective
action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the
corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Samantha Way at 517-243-9743.
Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CB820201144
Licensee Group Organization: Girlstown Foundation
Licensee Designee: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Chief Administrator: Jennifer Lynn Trotter
Name of Agency: Guiding Harbor
Agency Address: 525 E Huron River Dr
Belleville, MI 48111-3665
Agency Telephone #: 734-697-7242
Original Issuance Date: 05/20/1989
License Effective Date 06/10/2022
License Expiration Date 06/9/2024
Service Types: Place children for adoption, Certify foster
homes for license, Supervise Independent
Living, Place children in foster home,
Evaluate Applicants for adoption

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION
A. Consultant
Date(s) of On-site Inspection: 4/22/2024, 4/26/2024, 4/29/2024, 4/30/2024, 5/3/2024
Total No. Of No. of
Records Records
Reviewed
Current licensed foster homes 10 3
Homes pending licensure 13 3
Foster homes closed since the last inspection 1 1
Foster homes borrowed since the last inspection 2 2
Special Investigations in foster homes since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated child abuse and/or neglect
in foster care since last inspection 0 0
Incidents of substantiated corporal punishment in foster care
since last inspection 0 0
Children receiving direct foster care case management (placement in foster homes,
relative homes, CCI, hospital, etc.) 46 6
Children discharged from care during this period 4 3
Youth in independent living placement 3 3
Youth discharged from an independent living placement
since the last inspection 2 2
Applicants approved for adoption since the last inspection 8 3
Applicants denied for adoption since the last inspection 1 1
Closed child adoption cases since the last inspection 3 3
Open child adoption cases 15 3
Current employees who have worked at the facility for:
More than a year 11 11
Less than a year 12 4
Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 1
Adoption Staff 1
Supervisory Staff 1
Administrative Staff 2

B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
Licensed foster homes 10 3
Unlicensed relative homes 28 3
Number of persons interviewed:
Foster Parents 3
Foster Children 6
Relatives 3
Others (identify person interviewed by role) 0
III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except for
the following:
CPA Rule 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household must
have training in and maintain a current certification in
first aid and cardiopulmonary resuscitation from the
American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross, or other institution approved by the department.
Two of three open foster home records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the foster parent’s first aid and CPR certification
expired on 9/23/2023 and an update was not documented.
• A second record showed the foster parent’s first aid and CPR certification
expired on 8/16/2023; and it was not renewed until 10/8/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12324 Reevaluation.
(8) An agency shall complete a reevaluation and make
a licensing recommendation to the department at least
15 calendar days before the expiration date of the
foster home license.
One of three open foster home records reviewed showed the foster parent’s re-
evaluation report dated 11/14/2023 and renewal recommendation to the

Department on that same date were after the foster parent’s 11/7/2023 license
expiration date.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(a) A summary of the services provided during care up
to the time of the change in placement and the needs
that remain to be met.
One of three closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(a) as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12405 Change of placement.
(5) If an agency is no longer providing services to the
child in a foster home, then both the following must be
documented before a change in placement:
(b) Provision for any continuing services.
One of three closed foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of
(b) as required by the rule. The information was left blank.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:

(c) Available known information about the child's
health.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (c),
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (d),
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors
relating to the care of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (e),
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(f) All known behaviors of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (f),
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12417 Foster parent information.

(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all the
following information before the placement or
replacement of a child:
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of (g),
as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(3) When case responsibility changes from 1 child
placing agency to another child placing agency, a
modified service plan must be completed within 30
calendar days of the change in agency responsibility if
no other plan is done within 30 days. The plan must
address why the agency responsibility changed and
whether there are any modifications to existing service
plans.
One of six open foster child records reviewed where a 30-day report was due by
11/20/2024, did not show documentation of the 30-day report.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:
(c) Assessment of the placement selection criteria as
required under R 400.12404(4).
One of six open foster child records reviewed did not show documentation of the
child’s placement selection criteria, as required by this rule.
CPA Rule 400.12419 Initial service plans.
(1) The initial service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(a), must include all the following
information:

(h) The child behavior support plan to be used by the
foster parent.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed, the child’s initial service plan did
not show documentation of the specific behavior management support plan to be
used for the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12420 Updated service plans.
(1) An updated service plan, as required in R
400.12418(2)(b), must include all the following
information:
(g) A child behavior support plan that includes any
changes made since the previous plan and is to be
used by the foster parents.
In one of six open foster child records reviewed the child's updated service plan
did not show documentation of the specific behavior management support plan to
be used for the child.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12502 Program statement.
(2) An agency shall give a copy of the program
statement to a youth before placement in independent
living.
Three of three open independent living(IL) youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the program statement was provided to the youth
over eight months after the youth’s 1/4/2023 date of placement.
• A second and third record did not show documentation that the program
statement was provided to the youth.
Repeat Violation Established:

May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12503 Policy and procedures.
(3) An agency shall provide a youth in independent
living with a copy of the agency's policies and
procedures required by this rule.
Three of three open independent living(IL) youth records reviewed did not show
compliance:
• One record showed the policy and procedures were provided to the youth
over eight months after the youth’s 1/4/2023 date of placement.
• A second and third record did not show documentation that the policy and
procedures were provided to the youth.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(a) How the youth meets the eligibility requirements for
the specific program the youth is being placed into.
Two of three open IL youth records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
until 4/8/2023 and 4/11/2024 which was after the respective youth’s 1/4/2023 and
11/16/2023 date of placement.
CPA Rule 400.12504 Eligibility requirements.
(2) All the following must be in the case record before a
youth is placed in independent living:
(e) An evaluation of a youth's need for supervision and
a plan for providing the level of supervision determined
necessary.

Two of three open IL youth records reviewed did not show documentation of (a)
until 4/8/2023 and 4/11/2024, which was after the respective youth’s 1/4/2023 and
11/16/2023 date of placement.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
CPA Rule 400.12507 Medical, dental and mental health care.
(1) An agency shall ensure that a youth in independent
living receives any needed medical, dental, and mental
health care as required in R 400.12413. Medical,
dental, and mental health care provided must be
documented in the youth's record.
One of open three open IL records reviewed did not show documentation of the
youth’s annual medical examination due by 3/17/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12509 Independent living record.
(3) The case record must contain all the following
information and documentation, which must be
recorded within 30 calendar days after placement in
independent living and updated at least once every 90
calendar days:
(o) Service plans as required in R 400.12419 and R
400.12420. If the youth has biological children, the
service plan must address the living arrangement for
the child or children, visitation/parenting time with the
youth's biological children or a clear explanation why
this is not possible or appropriate.
One of three open IL youth records reviewed showed two late service plans:
• The youth’s 1/12/2023-4/22/2023 updated service plan (USP)was
completed 5 days late on 4/28/2023; and the youth’s 4/23/2023-
7/21/2023 USP was completed 2 days late on 7/24/2023.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2022 Renewal- cited under R400.12418(2)(b), CAP approved 6/8/2022.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.

(1) There must be a mutual agreement between the
youth and the agency specifying all the following:
(a) The responsibilities of the agency and the youth.
One of three open IL youth records reviewed showed the initial agreement due by
1/8/2024 was not completed until 4/10/2024.
CPA Rule 400.12510 Independent living agreement.
(1) There must be a mutual agreement between the
youth and the agency specifying all the following:
(c) An agreement to meet with the worker at least `1
time per calendar month.
One of three open IL youth records reviewed showed the initial agreement did
not show documentation of (c) as required by the rule.
CPA Rule 400.12605 Adoptive family evaluation.
(1) An agency social service worker shall complete a
written adoptive evaluation within 90 days of the family
signing an adoption application and prior to approving a
family for adoption.
Three of three adoptive family records reviewed showed the family’s written
adoptive evaluation was not completed within 90 calander days of the respective
family’s 2/1/2022, 10/27/2022 and 8/11/2023 application date.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Child Adoption Assessment Time Frames
The DHS-1927, Child Adoption Assessment, must be
completed by the adoption worker and approved by the
adoption supervisor within 45 calendar days of case
acceptance.

One of three closed child adoption records reviewed; and one of three open
adoption records reviewed did not show compliance:
• The first record showed the child’s adoption assessment due by
5/26/2023 was completed 14 days late on 6/9/2023.
• A second record showed the child’s adoption assessment due by
9/8/2023 was completed 12 days late on 9/20/2023.
Repeat Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
ADM 300 Child Adoption Assessment.
Child Adoption Assessment Addendum
The DHS-606, Child Adoption Assessment Addendum,
must be used to update the DHS-1927, Child Adoption
Assessment, on an annual basis if the child has not
been placed for adoption.
One of three open child adoption records reviewed showed an annual adoption
assessment addendum was not completed in 2022. After the child’s initial child
adoption assessment on 6/28/2021, another adoption assessment was not
completed until 7/24/2023.
Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
ADM 330 Adoption Quarterly Progress Report.
Quarterly progress reports, using the DHHS-614 are to
be completed each quarter.
One of three closed child adoption records reviewed; and three of three open
child adoption records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One record showed the child’s 4/19/2023-2023-7/18/2023,
7/19/2023-10/17/2023 and 10/18/2023-1/16/2024 were all
completed late on 5/7/2024.
• A second record showed the child’s 4/23/2023-7/22/2023 quarterly
was completed almost 2 months late on 9/15/2023. This child’s
10/6/2023-1/4/2024 quarterly was completed 1 day late on
1/5/2024.

• A third child’s 11/19/2023-2/17/2024 quarterly was completed 2
days late on 2/19/2024.
A fourth record showed the child’s 5/26/2023-8/24/2023 quarterly
was completed 17 days late on 9/11/2023. This child’s 8/25/2023-
11/23/2023 quarterly was completed 18 days late on 12/11/2023.
Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
FOM 722-6B Family Team Meeting.
Each meeting must be documented in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink and all of the appropriate
forms must be completed for each type of meeting.
Certain circumstances, events, and/or stages of case
progression mandate FTMs must occur within the
required time frames as out lined in the following table:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date. Note: This FTM may be
combined with the CPS Case Opening (ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) – within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date. Permanent Ward
Service Plan (PWSP) – within 30 calendar days before
the case plan due date.
Placement preservation/disruption-At least three
business days prior to a planned change of placement
or no later than three business days after an unplanned
placement change.
Semi-annual transition meeting- Within 30 calendar
days after the child’s 14th birthday and every six
months thereafter.
Two of six open foster child records reviewed; and one of three open IL youth
records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s record did not show an FTM for the child’s 4/3/2023-7/1/2023
or 7/2/2023-9/29/2023 USP.
• A second child’s record did not show documentation of a DHS-1105 for a
3/15/2024 FTM.

• The IL youth’s record did not show documentation of an FTM for the
youth’s 1/23/2023-4/22/2023 USP. Nor documentation of semi-annual
transition meeting due by 8/23/2023.
Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
FOM 722-8 D Treatment Plan.
Agreement and signature:
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must
obtain signatures from the following individuals, as
applicable:
Parents who are a member of a participating
household.
Youth ages 14 and older.
Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated
court ordered caregivers.
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all
applicable individuals and upload the signatures pages.
into the electronic case record within 30 days of the
report date.
Three of six open foster child records reviewed; and one of three open IL youth
records reviewed did not show compliance:
• One child’s 9/30/2023-12/28/2023- treatment plan was signed by
the birth father, but not dated; and I could not discern if it was
signed timely. Th document was uploaded 3/15/2024.
• A second child’s 12/23/2023-3/18/2024 treatment plan was not
signed by the caregiver until 4/30/2024.
• A third child’s 4/13/2023-7/11/2023, 7/12/2023-10/9/2023 and
10/10/2023-1/17/2024 treatment plan were not signed by caregiver.
• The IL youth’s 1/23/2023-4/22/2023; 4/23/2023-7/21/2023;
7/22/2023-10/19/2033 treatment plans were all not signed by youth
until 12/22/2023. This youth’s 10/20/2023- 1/17/2024 treatment plan
was signed by the youth; but not dated; and I could not discern if it
signed timely. It was uploaded 3/28/2024.

Violation Established:
May 2023 Interim, CAP approved 7/25/2023.
May 2022 Renewal, CAP approved 6/8/2022.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
R400.12607(4) Adoptive Recommendation:
• The agency was apprised it shall clearly and consistently show it provided a
copy of the evaluation to family timely.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
ADM 980 Closing Documentation:
• The agency was advised documenting the reason a Closing Summary’s
(DHS-222) completion was delayed by the court or department onto the DHS-
222 may aid it in showing compliance to this standard.
ADM 330 Quarterly Adoption Progress Report.
• The agency was advised placing the quarterly reporting period timeframe
onto the top of the report, may aid it in showing clearer documentation of the
accurate quarterly reporting period.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted two corrective action plans (CAP) during this period
under review.
The first corrective action plan related to Special Investigation 2023C000176,
which alleged the agency placed a child with an adult who was not legally related
to the child, nor a legal custodian or licensed foster parent. The agency was found
in violation of CPA Rule 400.12404(1). The agency’s submitted an acceptable
corrective action plan on 4/25/2023. The agency has not experienced another

situation similar to the one that lead to this special investigation. The agency
completed all other aspects of this corrective action plan.
The second CAP related to the agency’s 2023 Interim inspection completed on
5/23/2023 where the CAP was approved on 7/25/2023. The agency received 27
violations, 10 of which are repeat violations this year. The agency’s compliance
around these 10 rule violations is as follows: with the exception of R400.12502(2)
and R400.12503(3) where the number of individual cases cited increased from 2
of 2 to 3 of 3; the other 8 repeat violations number of individual cases cited, either
decreased or stayed the same.
In the agency’s 2022 Renewal inspection, 33 violations were established, 10 of
which were repeat violations this year. With the exception of a repeat violation for
R400.12605(1) where the number of individuals cases cited increased from 2 of 2,
to 3 of 3; and R400.12324(8) where the number of individual cases cited
deceased from 3 of 4, to 1 of 3, the other 8 repeat citations remained the same.
The agency made progress on its 2023 CAP. Its number of rule violations this
inspection stay the same from 2023 and decreased from 2022. The agency
completed the various trainings indicated in its CAP. They also showed sample
proofs of emails and calendar reminders, and discussions with staff related to
timeframes, key performance indicators, and CAP reviews. Notwithstanding the
agency’s progress with the 2023 CAP, the agency received the repeat violations
as cited in this report. The agency will need to develop further action steps and
continue its efforts with staff to advance rule compliance.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator (CA) provided a chief administrator’s assessment report
dated 4/3/2024. The CA reported that since the majority of the staff have been in
their roles for less than one year it has taken time to get them trained and
accustomed to their roles. The CA also reported the last CAP assisted the agency
in modifying their processes to improve compliance; that a foster care case aide
helped with sending reminder letters, calls and email to foster parent regarding
medicals/dentals and transportation. Additionally, a tracking system and reminders
during team meetings and individual supervisions has been used to improve the
timeliness of licensing, adoption and foster care reports and medicals and dentals.
The agency believes it has had compliance success with its quarterly CAP reviews
by the supervisory team; and it plans to continue this process.
Financial Overview
The agency provided a 2024 agency budget and the 2022 end of the year
independent financial audit. No major concerns were observed.
Staff Interviews
In additions to discussion with the chief administrator, program director,
licensing/adoption supervisor, and two foster care supervisors, I interviewed one
foster care worker, one adoption worker, one licensing worker, and one foster care
supervisor. The staff interviewed reported the smallness of the agency allows for

a close-knit family environment where everyone is willing to help and there is a
reliable team. The staff reported feeling appreciated and supported by the
administration. Areas of growth or improvement indicated was for more staff to be
hired so as to reduce staff responsibilities, continued improved communication
amongst all departments, and increased organization of forms and case records.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walk through of the facility showed the agency has ample office space and
equipment for its staff. Additionally, it showed case records were properly stored
and secured. There were no safety concerns observed.
VII. FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were two safety alerts received.
Safety Alert #1 received 3/13/2024:
Concern:
The foster parent refused to allow the Analyst’s visit; and the safety of the child and
the home could not be assessed.
Resolution:
When contacted by the agency, the foster parent admitted to not allowing the visit,
by the Analyst. The foster parent reported not doing so, because she wanted to
close her license. The agency reported, the child in the home had been adopted by
the foster parent on 2/1/2024. Additionally, that it commenced a special evaluation
on the foster home related to this matter on 3/14/2024. That upon the special
evaluation’s resolution the foster parent’s request for closure would be honored.
Safety Alert #2 received 4/8/2024:
Concern
The unlicensed relative home did not have an operable smoke detector in the
basement; and second bedroom on the main level was not viewed; there were
exposed electrical wires.
Resolution:
The agency provided the unlicensed relative with an operable smoke detector for
the basement on 4/9/2024. The agency reported the relative has a contractor re-
wiring the home and the project is in progress. The targeted date of completion is
6/1/2024. A safety plan was completed with the relative on 4/9/2024 related to
replacing the outlet covers, and missing light switch covers, ceiling light fixture and
supervision of the child during the contract work.

VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it
is recommended that the agency will be issued a renewal of their regular license.
May 14, 2024
_____________________________________
Lonia Perry Calloway Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
May 15, 2024
_____________________________________
Samantha Way Date
Area Manager
